questions.text: Given below is an instrument used for irrigation. In which of the following procedures will it not be used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Trephination The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula. It is used in irrigation of the maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell Luc operation. The direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside. Rose's sinus douching cannula is a medical instrument primarily used for irrigation or cleansing of the sinuses during certain procedures. It is used to irrigate the sinus cavities, ensuring that they are cleared of debris or infected material. Let’s break down the options: A. Intranasal antrostomy: In intranasal antrostomy, a surgical procedure is performed to create an opening between the maxillary sinus and the nasal cavity, usually to allow for drainage or to treat chronic sinusitis. Rose’s sinus douching cannula is often used for irrigation after such procedures to help cleanse the sinus and ensure proper drainage. Therefore, the cannula would be used in this procedure. B. Caldwell-Luc operation: The Caldwell-Luc operation is a procedure used to access the maxillary sinus through the maxillary bone to treat conditions like chronic sinusitis, remove polyps, or drain abscesses. Rose's sinus douching cannula is often used in post-operative care to irrigate the sinus, ensuring that it is clear of any residual material. Hence, the cannula would also be used in this procedure. C. Trephination: Trephination refers to a procedure where a hole is made in the skull or a sinus to relieve pressure, often for conditions like abscesses, or to allow drainage. However, this procedure does not typically involve irrigation through a cannula like Rose's sinus douching cannula, especially if the procedure is focused on draining a fluid collection. Therefore, the cannula would not be used in this procedure.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image is not used for which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Upper airway examination The image shows a tracheostomy tube. It is not used for upper airway examination. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.

choices.text: Reduction of the fracture of nasal septum
Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone
Punching out bone in DCR procedure

questions.text: What is the main use of the instrument seen in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reduction of the fracture of nasal bone The instrument seen in the image is Walsham forceps. It is is mainly used to reduce nasal bone fracture. Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce fracture of the nasal septum.

questions.text: A patient with hearing loss is being evaluated with the following instrument. What is the frequency of the probe used?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 220 Hz The given image shows impedance audiometry and the frequency of the probe used here is 220 Hz. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels. - To deliver a tone of 220Hz - To absorb reflected sound - To change the pressure in EAC

questions.text: What is the instrument shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Barany noise box The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box which is used to mask non-test ear while testing bone conduction.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing a mastoidectomy procedure. During the procedure, a surgeon uses the following instrument to explore the mastoid air cells. Name the given instrument
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MacEwen’s curette The above image is a MacEwen’s curette and cell seeker. During mastoid surgeries, one end is used to explore the air cells and the other end is used to curette the intervening septa and granulations

questions.text: An objective diagnostic test is performed on a patient who complains of loss of hearing on his right side. The following instrument is used to perform this test. What is this instrument known as?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tympanometer The image is of a tympanometer. It is used in evaluating the status of the middle ear. It is based on a simple principle that when a sound strikes the tympanic membrane, some of the sound energy is absorbed while the rest is reflected. A stiffer tympanic membrane would reflect more sound energy than a compliant one.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had fever and cough for 1 week, following which he developed a severe earache, decreased hearing, and a feeling of stuffiness in his left ear. Otoscopy revealed a bulging, erythematous tympanic membrane. He was managed with antibiotics. On follow-up after 12 weeks, persistent effusion was noted, and it was managed with the procedure shown below. Identify the instrument used in the procedure.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Myringotome The case described with fever, earache, erythematous, and bulging tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM), which is treated by antibiotics and incision of the tympanic membrane using a myringotome (myringotomy).

questions.text: The following instrument is used in which of the following surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) The given image is of a Blakesley straight forceps. It is used In functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) operations.

questions.text: The following instrument is used for.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Myringotomy The given instrument with an arrowed blade and angled shank is a myringotome. It is used for myringotomy.

questions.text: What is the marked structure of the cochlear implant shown below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ground electrode The marked structure in the radiology image of the cochlear Implant is the ground electrode. A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It can be used in a patient with bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with chronic sinusitis undergoes the following procedure to relieve him of his symptoms. Which of the following instruments is required to carry out this procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tilley-Lichtwiz trocar The procedure is proof puncture (antral lavage) which uses Tilley-Lichwitz trocar and cannula. They are used for the puncture of the lateral wall of the inferior meatus at a point 1.5-2.0cm from the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, near the attachment of concha with the lateral wall.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman has complaints of reduced hearing on her right side. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Digital audiometer The image is of a Digital audiometer. An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram.

questions.text: A surgeon is to perform a mastoidectomy procedure for a patient with CSOM. He uses the following instrument during the procedure. What is the name of the given instrument?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mollison’s mastoid retractor The above image shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy procedures to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

questions.text: A senior resident in the hospital is performing the following clinical examination as shown in the image below. Which of the following structures will not be visible to him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Arytenoids The senior resident would not be visualizing the arytenoids as he is performing a posterior rhinoscopy indicated by the post-nasal mirror that he is holding. The posterior rhinoscopy mirror (St. Clair Thompson mirror) has two bends in the shaft and is bayonet shaped.

questions.text: Which procedure is the following instrument not used in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) The image shows Luc’s forceps. It is not used in FESS.

questions.text: The following instrument is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ballenger swivel knife The image is of a Ballenger swivel knife. It is used in the removal of septal cartilage in SMR (Submucosal resection) operation. The blade of the knife revolves automatically and changes direction when cutting the cartilage anteroposteriorly downwards and posteroanteriorly. Different sizes of blades are present. It can be used to harvest septal cartilage as a graft for reconstruction.

questions.text: Identify the retractor shown in the below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mastoid retractor The instrument shown in the image is Mollison’s mastoid retractor. It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic

questions.text: Identify the retractor shown in the below image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mollison mastoid retractor The instrument in the image is a self-retaining retractor with a scissor-like handle and pronged tips. It has a ratchet mechanism, allowing it to stay in place once opened — typical of self-retaining surgical retractors. The blades are curved and notched, ideal for holding back soft tissue in narrow surgical fields like the ear canal.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with respiratory insufficiency. A decision is made to perform a procedure using the instrument shown below. Which of the following is not a function of this procedure?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Increase dead space by 30-50% The image shows a tracheostomy tube. Tracheostomy does not increase dead space by 30-50%. It decreases dead space and reduces airway resistance. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea.
